text.p: Jordan condemned a Wednesday bomb attack in a west Jerusalem street market which killed at least 13 people, blaming extremists who seek to wreck efforts to push the Middle East peace process forward.

"Extremists attack any glimmer of hope in pushing the peace process forward whenever the circumstances are created to resume talks or a breakthrough appears on the horizon...," a overnment spokesman told the state news agency Petra.
Amman expressed optimism on Tuesday about prospects of relaunching Israeli-Palestinian peace talks after Israel halted plans for a new Jewish settler enclave in Jerusalem.
"The Jordanian government condemns this terrorist attack which targets innocents regardless of its motives or the party that has executed it," the spokesman was quoted as saying.

The spokesman said the bombing was ..."aimed in the first place to put more obstacles and hurdles to aspirations of the peoples of the region for security, stability and prosperity under comprehensive peace."
But Jordan urged Israel not to give extremists what they wanted by being pushed by the attack to halt the peace process with the Palestinians, the spokesman said.
"Such terrorist attacks should only be a motive to resume negotiations and revitalise the stalled peace talks, not obstruct it," the official spokesman said.
"This is important to prevent the enemies of peace from attaining their aim," he added.
Jordan has repeatedly warned of a renewed cycle of violence amid growing frustrations over the slow pace of the peace process.
